The Sixteenth Year of GEORGE III.

An Act for continuing an Act, entitled, An Act for allowing further Time to Persons in Offices or Employments, to qualify themselves, pursuant to an Act, entitled, An Act to prevent the further Growth of Popery.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the fifteenth and fifteenth years of your Majesty's reign, entitled, An act for allowing further time to persons in offices or employments, to qualify tkemselves, pursuant to an act, entitled. An aci to prevent the further growth of popery, several provisions were made therein, which have been found to be of general use: and whereas the time limited by the said receited act, for the persons to qualify, as therein directed, will expire on the first day of August one thousiutd seven hundred and seventy fix; and whereas it will be expedient that further time shall be allowed to persons in offices or employments to qualify themselvcsj wherefore be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the time mentioned in the said receited act, for persons in offices or employments so to qualify themselves, shall be extended to the first day of July which will be in die year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight.

A.D.

GEORGE III.

CHAP. I.

An Act for granting unto His Majesty an additional Duty on Beer, Ale, Strong Waters, Wine, Tobacco, Hides, and other Goods and Merchandizes therein mentioned-, and for prohibiting the Importation of all Gold and Silver Lace, and of all Gambrkks and Lawns, except of the Manufacture of Great Britain.

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects the commons of Ire- A.D.

land in Parliament assembled, having a just sense of your royal care for 1777-8. the prosperity of all your subjects, and well knowing that the security of this realm, and the continuance of the many blelfings we enjoy under your Majesty's mild and auspicious reign, depend on the support of your Majesty's government: and whereas twelve thousand efleftive men, commission and non-commission officers included, arc necessary to be maintained within this kingdom for its defence: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That three thousand and forty six men, commission and non commission officers included, which have been raised in pursuance of an act of Parliament paflitd in this kingdom in the session of A 1 e-;

The seventeenth and eigheteqtb Years of George III.

one thousand seven hundred and sixty nine be continued for two years from the first day of January one thousand seven hundred and fevcmy eight to the thirty first day of December one thousand seven hundred and seventy nine inclusive} so as that the force# on the establishment in this Jdogdp.m may amount to fifteen thousand and forty six eflfective men, commission and non commission officers included, so foqu as the four thousand men, which have been sent by your Majesty out of this kingdom on account of the present exigency of affairs, shall be returned.

II. And in order to enable your Majesty to carry into execution your Majesty's intentions and determined resolution, signified to us by his excellency the lord viscount Townshend, late lord lieutenant of this kingdom, by your Majesty's command, to keep within this kingdom for the necessary defence of the fame twelve thousand effective men, commission and non commission officers included, at all times unless in cases of invasion or rebellion in Great Britain, and to defray the other necessary expences of your Majesty's government, we do most humbly beseech your Majesty, that it may he enacted and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and seventy seven until the twenty fifth day of December, which shall be in the year one thousand seven hundred and seventy nine inclusively, and no longer, there shall be throughout his Majesty's kingdom of Ireland granted, raised, collected, levied, and paid to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, the several rates, additional duties, and impositions herein after mentioned (that is to say) for and upon every thirty two gallons of beer or ale above the price of six shillings the barrel, brewed within this kingdom by any common brewer, or in his vessels, or by any other person or persons who doth, or do, or shall fell or tap out beer or ale publickly or privately, such gallon to contain twrf hundred and seventy two cubical incites, and one fourth part of a cubical inch, the sum of two shillings, to be paid by the common brewer, or by such other person or persons respectively, who shall brew, fell, or tap out the fame, and so proportionably for a greater or lesser quantity; and for every thirty two gallons of beer or ale of the price of six shillings or under, brewed within this kingdom by any common brewer, or in his vessels, or by any other person or persons who doth, or do, or shall fell or tap out beer or ale publickly or privately, each gallon to contain two hundred ami seventy two cubical inches, and one fourth part of a cubical inch, the sum of four pence, to be paid by the common brewer, or such other person or persons respectively, who shall brew, fell, or tap out the fame during the time aforesaid, and so proportionally for a greater or lesser quantity; for every gallon of aquavit®, strong waters, or spirits, made or distilled within this kingdom for falc, the sum of four pence, to be paid by the first maker or distiller thereof during the time aforesaid; for every pound weight of tobacco that Aval] be imported into this kingdom during the time aforesaid, the sum of three pence halfpenny; for every yard of muffin that shall be imported into this kingdom during the rime aforesaid, the sum of six pence; for every yard of all forts of (ilks and (tufis, made or manufactured in Persia, China, or the East Indies, that shall be imported into this kingdom during the time aforesaid, the sum of one (lulling and six pence; for every ton of wine that shall be imported into this kingdom during the time aforesaid, the sum of four pounds, and so proportionably for a greater or less quantity; for every gallon of brandy, strong waters, and spirits perfe£Uy made, and of spirits made and distilled of wine not above proof, that shall he imported into this kingdom during the time aforesaid, the sum of eight pence, and so proportionably for a greater or less quantity; and for every gallon of foreign spirits (above the quality of Angle spirits) which shall be imported into this kingdom during the time aforesaid, an additional duty shall be paid for such spirits, and shall be charged thereon, in proportion to the duties payable for Angle spirits 3 of

of the fame denomination, according to the comparative degree of strength, which A.D. such spirits so to be imported shall bear to Angle spirits of the fame denomina-tion; for and upon every pound weight of coflee, chocolate, and cocoa nuts, that jt

CHAP. IV.

An Act for granting to his Majesty an additional Duty upon the five-ral Goods and Merchandizes therein mentioned.

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects, the commons of Ire- £«»M at land in Parliament assembled, as a further supply to your Majesty to Dcc' I’7', support the expences of your Majesty's government, do most humbly beseech your Majesty, that it may be enacted, and be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the -fame, That from and after the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and seventy seven until the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and seventy nine inclusive, there shall be raised, levied, collected, and paid, the several rates and additional duties herein after mentioned, that is to say, an additional duty of one dulling per hundred weight upon all flour, meal, bread, and biscuit, except of the produce and manufacture of Great Britain, imported into this kingdom; an additional duty of two (hidings per barrel upon all wheat, except of the produce of Great Britain, imported into this kingdom, uu-less the middle price of wheat at the port, where the same shall be imported, shall exceed the price of twenty three shillings English per barrel at the time of such importation; the said price to be ascertained as directed by an act of Parliament made and passed in the twenty ninth year of his late Majesty King George the second, entitled, An act for the further encouragement f tillage.

JI. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all and every the several and respective additional duties, rates, and impositions hereby granted, shall be raised, answered, collcfled, and paid unto his Majesty, his heirs and successors, during the time aforesaid, at the same time, in the like manner, and by such ways, means, and methods, and under such penalties and forfeitures, and with such powers, as are appointed, directed, and expressitd for the railing, colicfling, and paying the duties therein mentioned, in and by an act made in this kingdom in the fourteenth and fifteenth years of the reign of his late Majesty King Charles the 'second, entitled, An abb fir the settling of the excifi or new impofi upon his Majesjt his heirs and successors, according to the booh of rates therein insertcdt or by any other law now in force relating to the revenue of excise in this kingdom, as folly and effectually to all intents and purposes as if the fame were particularly mentioned, expressed, and enacted again in the body of this present act, with like remedy of appeal to and for the party grieved as in and by tire said act, or any other law or laws now in being relating to the duties of excise, is provided.

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That neither the lit pence per pound, nor any other fee, shall be payable to nor be dedufled or re* ccived by the vice treasurer or vice treasurers, receiver, or paymaster general, clerk of the pells, or any other officer or officers of this kingdom, for or on account of the issuing or payment of any sum or sums of money arising by, or which shall be received for or on account of, tile aids hereby granted to his Majesty, or any payment to be made in pursuance of this act.

CHAP. V.

An Act for allowing further Time to Persons hi Offices or Employments to qualify themselves pursuant to an Act, entitled, An Act to prevent the further Growth of Popery.

WHEREAS several. persons, well affected to his Majesty's government, and the church of Ireland, as by law established, may have through ignorance neglected,or been prevented by sickness,or other unavoidable causes, from taking and subscribing die oaths, and making, repeating, and subscribing the declaration, and from receiving the sacrament of the Lord's Supper, and delivering a certificate thereof, according to the directions of an act made in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late. Majesty Queen Anne, entitled. An act to prevent the further growth of popery, and may thereby have incurred great penalties: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every person or persons, who have incurred any penalties and incapacities in the said act, entitled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery} mentioned, by neglecting to qualify themselves according to the said act, shall be and are hereby indemnified, freed, and discharged of and from all incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, and penalties, incurred by reason of such oniiflion or neglect as aforesaid; and that no act or acts done by them, or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be questioned or avoided by reafou of such neglect or omission; but all such acts shall be, and are hereby declared and enacted to be, as good and effectual, ns if all and every such person and persons had taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and delivered a certificate thereof, and made, repeated, and subscribed the said declaration, at such time, place, and manner as is therein mentioned; any thing in the said act to the contrary notwithstanding.

II. Provided always, That such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and receive the said sacrament, and make, repeat, and subscribe the said declaration, in such manner and form, and in such place and places, as are directed and appointed by the said act to prevent the further growth of popery, on or before the first day of May, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight.

III. And whereas several of his Majesty's subjects are often preferred in the army, while they are residing in Great Britain, whereupon they are by the laws in force in that kingdom obliged to qualify themselves in some part of Great Britain by receiving the sacrament, taking the oaths, and subscribing the declaration thereby required, within the time mentioned in such laws: and whereas the regiment or regiments, iu winch such officer or officers have commissions so granted to them, are often ordered into this kingdom, and put upon this establishment, by which a doubt li3S arisen, whether such officer or officers, notwithstanding his or their having qualified themselves in Great Britain for such commission according to the said laws, are not by the laws in force in this kingdom obliged to qualify themselves after their arrival here for such commissions according to an act of Parliament, passed in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty queen Anne, entitled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no officer or officers so preferred in Great Britain, who shall have qualified him or themselves for such commission or commissions according to and within the time limited by the said laws made in Great Britain, shall be obliged to qualify him or themselves in this kingdom for such commission

or

XVI. Provided also, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act, or any thing herein contained, shall not extend or be condrued to give any power for licensing any hawker, pedlar, or petty chapman, to sell or expose to sale any wares, or merchandizes in any city, borough, town corporate, or market town within this realm, any otherwise than he or (lie might have done before the making of this act any thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

The seventeenth and eighteenth years of George III.

former brewing of wort or guile so gauged by the gauger or officer at his last visit, and shall be charged accordingly; and every common or retailing brewer so offending shall, for every barrel so encreased over and above the quantity contained in the said former brewing, forfeit the film of five pounds; and the servant or servants of such brewer who was or were any way knowingly concerned or assisting in making such new brewing or increase of wort or guile, shall forfeit for every barrel, so newly brewed or increased, the sum of twenty shillings, and for default of payment thereof shall suffer three months imprisonment.

XVII. And whereas common and retailing brewers for the purpose of bringing into their flock beer and ale clandestinely brewed do frequently on the turning out beer and ale replace the fame with empty calks or calks of water or taplalh, and by mixing such calks with their stock, and by placing on the upper part of such calks froth or barm do impose upon the officers of the revenue, and shew and declare the lame to them as beer or ale and part of their stock, thereby obtaining credit for more beer or ale in stock than they are intitled to: for remedy whereof be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the said twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight every common or retailing brewer of beer or ale, or his or her servant, who shall shew his or her stock to the officer, shall count all the calks of beer, ale, guile, or worts, and declare the number of each denomination to the officer so taking an account of the fame; and in case such common or retailing brewer, his or her servant, shall refuse so to do, he, she, or they shall forfeit for every such offence the sum of twenty pounds; and if after the said declaraion as aforesaid there shall be found any empty calk, or any calk containing any other liquor or thing, save only what they were declared to contain, or any calks more than one of each denomination, but in part full, or a greater number of calks in the whole than have been declared, such common or retailing brewer shall forfeit for every calk, so found contrary to such declaration, the sum of forty shillings; and when such declaration shall be made, the account of the stock of beer, ale, guile, or worts of any brewer so declared, shall be deemed and taken to be the stock of such brewer at the time of taking the same.

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that any pecuniary penalties, created by this act, for the recovery of which no mode is herein before prescribed, shall be recoverable before two or more justices of the peace in the county, city, town, or place, in which the offence shall be committed, or before two or more justices of the peace in the county where such offenders shall be resident, on proof of the offence by the oath or oaths of one or more credible witness or witnesses, or on confession of the offender j and the penalty so recovered shall belong to the informer or informers prosecuting for the fame; and in case of non payment shall be levied by distress and lale of the offender’s goods and chattles, by warrant under the hands and seals of such justices, and the overplus of the money raised, after deducing the penalty, and the expences of the distress and sale, shall be rendered to the owner; and for want of sufficient distress, the offender shall be sent by such justice to the prison of such county, city, town, or place, for such term, not exceeding six months, as such justices shall think most proper.

An Act for incorporating the Charitable Musical Society for lending out Money Interest free to indigent and indufrious Tradesmen,

WHEREAS in the city of Dublin and suburbs thereof, there arc always a great number of industrlous tradefinen, who from their extreme poverty are unable to support themselves and families,*when visited by sickness or any other calamity, and are often incapable of earning to themselves a livelihood for want of money to buy materials and other necessaries for carrying on their respective trades; whereby Vox,. Sentence on conviction under this act to be immediately passed, and execution next day but one after, unless court fee reasonable cause for portioning it.

several of that useful class of men have perished, and their fa-1777-8. milies been reduced to beggary and become a burthen to the publick: for remedy whereof a voluntary society was instituted Avoiun- in the year one thousand seven hundred and fifty six, for the inftmiuifL purpose of lending out money interest free to indigent tradesmen: 175S for_and whereas the good effects of the said institution were so ra-dis-ent tndtf- pidly and powerfully felt, that large sums were collected, and men interetl many persons of quality and distinction contributed largely to the aid and support of the said charity, whereby several thousand families were relieved in the space of a few years: and whereas great benefits are likely to arise from such institution to the kingdom of Ireland in general, and to the city of Dublin in particular, by considerably encreasing the number of inhabitants therein, and promoting the trade and manufactures thereof, whereby the inhabitants of said kingdom will be more able to

contribute to the increase of the revenue, and the support of the establishment, and it might greatly promote the good ends aforesaid, if corporations of the like kind were established in the different manufacturing counties and market towns of this kingdom: and whereas divers persons are willing to contribute large sums of money for the good cutis and purposes aforesaid, but the said voluntary society are not capable in law of taking or receiving such contributions, or of carrying their good intentions effectually into execution, unless they be incorporated by an act of Parliament, with such clauses, powers, jurisdictions, and authorities, as are usual in such like cases: be it therefore en-

XI. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall and may be lawful to and for the said corporation, or any seven of them, whereof the president or one of the vice pre-fidents to beone, at any of the said stated general meetings to make or execute leases of any lands or tenements belonging'to the said corporation for any term not exceeding three lives if for lives, and if for years not exceeding thirty one years, to commence and take effect in possession, and not in reversion, or by way of future interest; upon which lease shall be reserved during the continuance of the said lease the best yearly rent, that can be got for the fame, without fine, gratuity, or other reward, which rent shall be made payable half yearly on the two usual feasts of the year, on which rents are made payable.

XII. Provided always, that the leal of the said corporation shall not be affixed to any lease, which has not been referred to a committee, who shall report, that the lease under consideration is a proper one, and is by deed indented, and that it contains the usual powers of distress and re-entry for nonpayment of rent; which lease, so made under the seal of the corporation, shall be read as evidence in all courts of record without any further proof.

XIII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said Corporation, or any five of them, at any general meeting shall have power to lend such sum or sums of money interest free to such person or persons, as they, shall think fit, not less than forty shillings nor more than five pounds, to any one person at any one time, to be repaid at such times and in such sums and proportions, as they shall think reasonable; for which sums so borrowed notes shall be passed by the borrower mentioning the terms of the loan.

CHAP. XIII.

An act for establishing a militia in this Kingdom.

WHEREAS a well regulated militia would conduce to The King strengthen the civil power, and to protest the land -. there-fore be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and millions to with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that his Majesty, his heirs and successors, ing militia or the chief governor or governors for the time being of this pl"" kingdom, may from time to time for or in respect to any county therein, wherein he or they may fee occasion lb to do, issue forth a commission or commissions of lieutenantcy and array to such person or persons, being protestants, as his Majesty, his heirs and successors, or the chief governor or governors, shall think fit, to be deputy lieutenants, or commissionevs of array in and for liich county, wherein such occasion shall be thought to exist, for arraying the militia therein during his Majesty's pleasure according to the regulations of this act.

XXXIX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the grand juries of the different counties may he impowered to grant by presentment, to be levied on the count}' at large, any sum not exceeding ten pounds per annum to the clerk of the commissioners of array.

XL. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no deputy lieutenant, or commissioner of array, captain or lieutenant, to be appointed by virtue of this act, shall act under such appointment, until they shall first have taken the oath of allegiance, and made, repeated, and subscribed the declaration, appointed by law to be taken by persons holding offices or employments under the crown.

XLI. Provided also, That if any person shall act as a deputy lieutenant, or commissioner of array, captain or lieutenant, in the militia without first filing with the clerk of the peace of the county, wherein he shall so ad, an affidavit, that he is duly qualified, as this act directs, for the office, to which he is or shall be appointed, every such person shall forfeit the sum of one thousand pounds, to be recovered by auy person who shall sue for the same in any of his Majesty's four courts at Dublin by bill, plaint, or information, wherein no wager of law, or more than one essoign, shall be allowed.

XLII. Provided also, That every person, appointed to the office of captain in any militia in any county in this kingdom, shall be intitled to a commission of the peace in and for the said county, paying the usual and accustomed fees.

X. Provided also, That all persons, who have conveyed, embezzled, or converted to their own use any monies, goods, wares, or merchandizes of persons, who have employed or intruded them, shall be excluded from receiving any benefit or advantage by this act.

XI. An act to amend and continue an act pafed in the thirteenth and fourteenth years of his present Majesty, entitled, An act for the better regulation of the baking trade in the city of Dublin, and for other purposes.

Produce of IT WHEREAS the present table for regulating the assize of whnTihted W bread is confessedly inaccurate, as Rating the produce of too high, the quarter of wheat higher, than it is found to be by the most

accurate experiments} from whence a necessity arises of impowering the magistrate to vary the allowance to the baker, as the price of wheat and flour varies, which creates much trouble to the magistrate, and occasions frequent disputes between him and the baker: and whereas it is therefore judged expedient to ascertain, as near as may be, the just quantity, which a quarter of wheat shall be supposed to produce, and to fix a certain reasonable allowance, to the baker, which shall never vary, except when the increase of his necessary expences in baking may re-instead of quire it: be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and h7’7h1d °d tempora^ anl' commons in this present parliament assembled, and whit* by the authority of the same, that from the twenty fourth annexed(aW' June one thousand seven hundred and seventy eight

V. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said commissioners of his Majesty's revenues shall at the beginning of every session of parliament lay before both houses of parliament an account in writing, of what number of ships have been employed in the whale fishery, with their respective names and burthens, from whence they were fitted out, and at what port they were discharged, and also what quantity of oil or whale fins each ship shall have imported.

VI. And whereas it has been found by experience, that ships under the burthen of two hundred tons are fit for the whale fishery: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that every owner or owners of any ship or ships under the burthen of two hundred tons, which shall be employed in the said fishery, and which shall be provided with sailors, boats, lines, and harpoons, in the fame proportion to the number of tons in said ship, as is hereby provided for ships of two hundred tons and upwards, and who have otherwise conformed themselves in all respects to the rules and directions herein before prescribed to the owners of ships of two hundred tons, (Itall be intitled to the said bounty, as herein before limited, according to the admeasurement of such ship or ships respectively.

VII. Provided always, an'.. that no ship to be employed in laid fishery, although flic be above the burthen of four hundred tons, shall be intitled to fi larger bounty, than a ship of four hundred tons would be intitled to.

VIII. Provided also, that nothing herein contained shall extend to oblige the owner of any ship above four hundred tons in order to intitle him or them to the said bounty to fit out, equip, and man any such ship otherwise than as a ship of the burthen of four hundred tons only, as by this act required to be fitted out, equipped, and manned.

CHAP. XIX.

An act for the better preservation of ffi in rivers, lakes, and inland waters.

Repealed An Act to explain and amend the ABs made for the Encouragement cJ/5! 2* of the Fj/heries of this Kingdom, and for promoting the good Ends proposed bp said Laws.

WHEREAS the extending and improving the Blheriea on the coast of v Ireland is of great importance to this kingdom, as it not only adds considerably to the national wealth, but may moreover prove a fruitful iiurfery of able teamen to the fleet of 0 Great Britain: for the better encouragement of the said lilheries, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the commencement of this act it shall and may be lawful to and for the inhabitants of this kingdom of Ireland at all times and seasons of the year, when they shall think proper, freely to fish for, tale, buy from fishermen, and cure any herrings, cod, and ling, or other fort of white lish, in all and every part of the seas, channels, creeks, and bays, wheresoever such lish are to be found, or can or may be taken on the coasts of this kingdom; and that no person or persons shall under any pretence whatsoever presume to obstruct or hinder any person or persons from fishing in the places aforesaid.

X. And whereas by an act passed in the third year of the reign of his present Majesty, entitled. An act for the encouragement of the fifties of this kingdom, a bounty is given of two shillings for every barrel containing thirty two gallons, wherein good found, and well cured white herrings shall be packed, upon the exportation thereof, as also a bounty of two shillings and six pence on every batcel of the fame contents, wherein good, found, and well cured mackarel shall be packed, upon exportation thereof: be it further enacted by die authority aforesaid, That the said bounties shall be paid in proportion upon all such herrings and maka-rel respectively, as shall be exported in calks of a letter size than thirty two gallons, upon the exportation diereof.

XI. And to* the end diat the vessels employed in the fisheries of this kingdom may be die more readily known, and the matters and crews of such vessels more easily brought to punittiment for any offences committed by them or any of them against this act, or the other acts made for the encouragement of said fisheries, be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That before any person shall be permitted to enter a vessel in any cuttom house for said fisheries, the owner of such vessel or his agent shall cause the name of said vessel and the port, to which flic belongs, to be painted in large characters with white lead and oil on the transum and quarters of said vessel, as also upon all boats and buoys belonging to the fame; and the collector shall cause a number to be added to such name, which number shall be inserted in the entry and painted in like manner on said vessel and on the boats and buoys belonging to her, which names and number Dial! not be obliterated, but kept fair and legible during the time said vessel shall remain at said fishery $ and in case said names and number shall not be kept fair and legible as aforesaid, the matter or chief officer of said vessel shall forfeit the sum of five pounds sterling, to be recovered and applied in the same manner as the other penalties in this act.

And for the better ascertaining the quantity of herrings taken and bought, be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That every vessel at the time of her being entered for the fisheries shall have on board two half barrels, each containing sixteen gallons, with which shall be measured the herrings taken and bought by berj and the entry in the journal of the quantity of herrings taken and bought shall be by the number of barrels or half barrels, and not by tail or count.

XIV. And whereas a great number of small boats proceed .‘.very year to the fiflicrics on the epafts of this kingdom, and from the irregular manner in which they (hoot their nets the fishery is greatly injured, and the nets of other fishermen are much damaged, and the offenders cannot be discovered so as to be brought to justice; be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no boat shall proceed to said (iflicries, unless tile name of the (kipper is painted in large characters with white lead and oil on the (tern of said boat, as also on the oars and buoys belonging to her; which boat, with the name of the (kipper, shall be registered with some one of his Majesty's justices of the peace living in the barony, wherein said Dripper resides: and in case any such'boat shall (hoot any net, or take any fish, without haring the (kipper’s name painted and being registered as aforesaid, the (kipper of said boat shall forfeit the sum of forty shillings, to be recovered and applied in the same manner as the other penalties in this aS; and any justice of the peace, with whom such boats shall be so registered, shall return an account of the same to the collector of the distrifl, in which such justice resides, within one month after such boats have been registered as aforesaid.

XVI. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That any person, Avho shall drudge for or tate any oyiters in any part of the lough of Carlingford between the bar of Carlingford and the cattle of Narrow-water from and after the first Saturday in the month of March until the (irft Monday in the month of November in any year, shall forfeit the drudge net or other machine, with which the fame shall be drudged for or taken, as also the sum of forty shillings, to be recovered and applied in the same manner as the other forfeitures and penalties in this act.

XVII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the several penalties and forfeitures imposed by this act, except where the same are othertrife appointed to be recovered, shall and may be recovered before any justice of peace of the county, where the offence is committed, or wherein the party or parties do reflde, and Be levied by distress and sale of his or their goods and chattles by warrant under the hand and seal of such justice, before whom the offence shall be proved by confeflioh, or on the oath of one credible witness; which said penalties and forfeitures, when recovered, shall go to the use of the person or persons, who shall sue for the same within twelve calendar months, next after the offence has been committed.

CHAP. XXIV.

An Act to prevent the Mfchiefs that arise from driving Cattle within the City of Dublin and Liberties thereof

WHEREAS the improper and cruel manner, in which cattle are driven Sipiicd r:s(.

through the streets and liberties of the city of Dublin, has occasioned great mischief, and endangered the lives of many of his Majesty's liege subjects inhabiting therein: for preventing whereof for the future, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the passing of this act if any person or persons, who shall be hired or employed to drive any cattle within the said city of Dublin, or the liberties thereof, shall by negligence or ill usage in the driving such cattle be the means, that any mischief shall be done by such cattle, or by any one or more of them, which shall be committed to his, her, or their care; or if any driver or drivers of cade within the limits aforesaid shall in any wise misbehavehimself, herself, or themselves, in the driving, care, or management of any such cattle, by the improper driving, treating, or using of such cattle, then and in any of said cases, and so often as any of them shall happen, it shall and may be lawful to and for any constable or other peace officer upon view thereof, or information of any person or persons, who shall declare his, her, or their name or names, and place or places of abode, to the said constable or other peace officer, to seize and secure by the audio, rity of this act, and without any other warrant to convey such offender or offenders before some justice of the peace of the said city of Dublin, or liberties thereof; and the party or panics accused being brought before such justice, within whole jurisdicttion the offence (ha! An act for continuing an act, entitled, An act for amending an act passed in the twenty ninth year of the reign of his late Majest] King George the second, entitled. An act for the further encouragement of tillage.

WHEREAS an act passed in the thirteenth year of the reign of his present Majesty, entitled, An act for amending an act passed in the twenty ninth year of king George IIe second, entitled. An act for the further encouragement of tillage, hath been found beneficial to this kingdom: be it enacted by the king’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that the said act may be continued until the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and eighty one.

CHAP. XXXIII. l77T

An Act for preventing the cutting or defraying of plain, fiained, or printed linens, cottons, lawns, or muslins, or any other manufactured goods.

WHEREAS the printing and Raining linens, cottons, and muslins is at present, and has been for several years palt, a very considerable manufacture in this kingdom, and of great national importance, as it gives employment to many persons of both sexes, has produced an additional home and foreign consumption of Irish linens, and is still capable of many further improvements: and whereas sundry evil minded disorderly persons have at different times for some time past cut anddestroyed garments of plain, printed, and Rained linens, cottons, lawns, and muslins on the wearers backs, and have also in a riotous and disorderly manner gone into the fliops, warehouses, andbleachgteensof several per-i'ons, who were artificers of the said manufacture and of other manufactures of this kingdom, and there cut and destroyed the same to the great prevention of the increase and consumption of the said manufacture j and at length arrived at such a degree of daring insolence as to threaten the lives and properties of many use* ful and industrious inhabitants, and to march through several of the principal streets in the city of Dublin, and denounce vengeance with the moll horrid threats against all-wearers and venders of printed manufactures, and presumed to disperse printed hand bills declaratory of such their dangerous and illegal inten- tions; by means whereof considerable quantities of the said manufactures remain undisposed of in the hands of the several persons, who dealt therein, to their great loss and injury: be it eua&ed by the king’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that from and after the first day of May one thousand liven hundred and seventy eight all and every person or persons Tocut or whatsoever, who shall wilfully or maliciously cut or otherwise.de- f^"cottons, stroy any plain, painted, Rained, or printed linens, cottons, lawns, ja«, muf-or muslins, or any manufactured goods of wool, Rile, or hair, when of lii^wooil* in wear or use of any person or persons whatsoever, or in the blcachgrcen, warehouses, fliops, or any other place whatsoever or in bicach-in this, kingdom, or shall destroy any wool, and shall be thereof Vot. An act to explain and amend an act, passed in the sixth year of lii reign of his present Majesty, entitled, An act for encouraging the planting of timber trees.

t> G. j. c. WHEREAS y an act passed in the sixth year of the reign '7‘ W of his present Majesty, entitled, An act for encouraging

the planting of timber trees, it is among other things enacted, that from and after the first day of September one thousand seven hundred and sixty six if any tenant for life or lives by settlement, dower, curtesy, jointure, lease, or any office, aril, military, or ecclesiastical, impeachable of waste, or any tenant for years exceeding twelve years unexpired, shall plant fall)', oiier, or willow, the sole property of such shall during the continuance of the term vest in the tenant, and he may cut and sell the same under the restrictions therein after mentioned; and if such tenant shall plant any timber trees of oak, alh, elm, firr, plane, wallnut, chesnut, horse chesnut, quick, or wild alh, alder, poplar, or other timber trees, such tenant during the term shall be entitled to a house boot, plow boot, cart boot, or car boot, of such trees by him planted; and at the expiration, or when such trees shall have attained maturity, which shall first happen, shall be entitled to the said trees or the value of them, according to the directions therein after mentioned, any covenant heretofore made, law, or usage to the contrary notwithstanding; and by the said act it is provided, that where the expiration of the term is certain, the tenant during the last year of his term paying the rent, and performing the covenants, may cut and carry away the trees by him planted: and whereas considerable parts of the

WHEREAS an act passed in the thirteenth year of the reign of his late Majesty George the second, entitled, An act for the repairing the road leading Jrom the town of Nenagb in 13 ft a. c. the county of Tipperary through the towns of Birr and Firbane in tin King’s county, to Curranaboy-bridge on the turnpike road leading to Alhione in the county of Westmeath: and whereas the said road is at present in a very bad date, and it is found by experience, that the tolls and duties, granted and made payable by the said act, have not been sufficient to keep the fame in sufficient order and repair, and also to make a. reasonable provision for such creditors as aforesaid, and that notwithstanding the expence already made thereupon, the said road is now in a ruinous condition: and whereas the tolls and duties granted by the said act were to take place and continue from the second day of June one thousand seven hundred and forty for forty years and no longer, and it is found expedient to make the several provisions herein after mentioned for the more effectually amending and repairing the said road, and keeping the fame in good order and repair, and for paying the debts now due on account of the said roads to the honest and fair creditors: be it enacted by the king’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords Ipirjtual and temporal and commons in this present

VI. And for the better avoiding all doubts and controversies concerning the several kind of hides and skins, and pieces of hides and skins, chargeable by this act, be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That by tanned hides or skins, or by tanned pieces of hides or skins, are meant only such as are tanned in ooze made of the bark of trees, or fumack, or whereof the principal ingredients shall be such bark or fumack j and that by hides and skins drafted in oil, or pieces of hides and skins drelfed in oil, are meant such as are made into leather in oil, or with any liquor or material whereof the chiefest ingredients shall he oil j and that by tawed hides or skins, or by tawed pieces of hides or skins, are meant such as are drclTed or made into icather in allum, and salt or meal, or other ingredients, properly used by the tawers of white leather.

VII. II. III. Provided that for every printed almanack or calendar, made to serve for several years, the respective rates aforesaid shall be paid for every such year; for all papers containing publick news, intelligence, or occurrences, a duty of one halfpenny for every sheet and piece of paper less than a (licet, on which such news, intelligence, or occurrences, shall be printed; for every pamphlet or paper not exceeding (ix (beets in octavo, or in a Idler page, or not exceeding twelve llicets in quarto, or twenty sheets in folio, so printed, a duty after the rate of one shilling (terling for every sheet of any kind of paper, which shall be contained in one printed copy or impression thereof; for every advertisement to he contained in or published with any gazette, news paper, or journal, to be published weekly or oftner, or in any other printed paper or pamphlet whatsoever, being dispersed or made publick yearly, monthly, or at any other interval of time, the sum of two pence.

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That every deed, inurement, note, memorandum, letter, or other muniment or writing, for or relating to the payment of any sum of money, or for making any valuable consideration for or upon the loss of any ship, vessel, goods, wages, money, cITcfts, or upon any loss by fire, or for any loss whatsoever, or for or upon any life or lives, shall be condrued, deemed, and adjudged to be policies of assurance within the meaning of this act.

V. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That every deed, instrument, note, memorandum, letter, or other muniment or writing, between the captain or mailer, or owner of any ship or vessel, and any merchant, trader, or other person, in respect to the freight or conveyance of any money, goods, wares, mctchandizes, or eflcfts, laden, or to be laden on board of any such ship or vessel, shall be deemed and adjudged to be a charter party within the meaning of this act.

CHAP. IV.

An Act for the Advancement of the Trade of this Kingdom. WHEREAS it is deemed reasonable and for the advancement of trade,

and encouragement of manufacture, that all goods and merchandize the product or manufacture of (his kingdom, which may by law be exported directly from this kingdom to any of the British plantations in America or the West Indies, or into any of the settlements belonging to Great Britain on the coalt of Africa, should Hand chargeable with and pay duties to the fame amount, and no more, and be exported thither upon the fame terms in respect of duties as goods and merchandize of the fame denomination and quality, the product or manufacture of Great Britain, exported thence to any of the said places, are now subject to or (land chargeable with, except as herein after excepted: and whereas no subsidy or duty is now payable in Great Britain on any goods or merchandize the product or manufacture of Great Britain upon their being exported thence to any of the said places, except upon allum, lead, lead ore, tin, leather tanned, copperas, coals, wool cards, white woollen cloths, tapis calaminaris, skins of all forts, glew, coney hair or wool, hare’s wool, hair of all forts, horses, and litharge of lead: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with tire advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the twenty fifth day of December, one thousand seven hundred and seventy nine, and until the twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty inclusive, the several and respective customs, fublidics, and ali other duties whatsoever payable to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, by any law now in force upon the exportation of any goods or merchandizes the product or manufacture of this kingdom shall cease and determine, and be no longer due, or payable for so much of the said goods and merchandizes, as shall during said time be exported directly from this kingdom to any of the British plantations in America or the West Indies, or any of the settlements belonging to Great Britain on the coast of Africa, except the several goods and merchandizes of the fame denomi. nation and quality as those herein before mentioned, whereon the subsidy or duty payable in Great Britain upon their export thence to any of the said places is dill payable; that is to say, allum, lead, lead ore, tin, leather tanned, copperas, coals, wool cards, white woollen cloths, lapis calamvuiris. skins of all forts, glew, coney hair or wool, hare’s wool, hair of all forts, horses, and litharge of lead, and also except amber grease, allies, bacon, beef, bones not manufactured, candles, butter, live cattle of all forts, chcefe, dye fluff of all forts, furs of all kinds, greaves, grease, guts, Iing’s lard, hoops, hops, horn, or tips of horns not manufactured, kelp, linen rags and (breads, linen yarn, okcr, oars of all forts, pork, provisions of all forts, except fish, corn, meal, malt, flour and grain of all forts, when the prices thereof exceed those, on or below which a bounty is payable on export by any law or laws now in force in this kingdom, rape cakes, threads or points of teacher, soap, foaper’s waltc, (laves, tallow, tongues, tin unwrought, weld, wax, and woad, bar iron, flit, rolled, or plated iron, or manufactured iron ware, vellum and parchment, and kid's hair.

An Act for establiflAng a Lottery, and for granting to his Majesty 19 & 20C,.}. a Sum of two hundred thousand Pounds to be raised thereby., and w' ' forfneb other Purposes as are therein mentioned.

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects, the commons of Ireland in Parliament assembled, do most humbly beseech your Majesty, that towards making good such deficiencies, as have arisen or may arise in the aids granted heretofore or during this session of Parliament for the support of your Majesty's government, a sum not exceeding the film of two hundred thousand pounds shall be raised by way of lottery, in such manner and form as herein after directed; and for that purpose be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent -of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the said lottery shall conlift of forty two thousand tickets (that is to say) forty thousand tickets to be paid for by the persons contributing thereto at the rate of five pounds for each ticket, and two thousand tickets to be given to the said persons without payment, in the manner herein after mentioned.

XXXIX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that from and after the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and seventy nine if any person or persons shall fell, procure, or deliver any ticket, receipt, chance, or number in or belonging to any foreign lottery, or pretended foreign lottery, or in or belonging to any class, part, or division of any such lottery, or pretended lottery, or in or belonging to any undertaking whatsoever in the nature of a lottery, or shall fell, procure, or deliver any ticket, receipt, chance or number in or belonging to any duplicate or pretended duplicate of any foreign lottery, or pretended foreign lottery, or shall receive or cause to be received any money whatsoever for any such ticket, receipt, chance, or number, or for or in confederation of any money to be repaid in case any ticket or tickets, number or numbers, in any foreign lottery, or pretended foreign lottery, or any class, part, or division thereof, shall prove fortunate, the person convicted thereof shall for every such offence forfeit the sum of two hundred pounds.

XL. Provided always, and be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that nothing herein contained shall extend or be construed to extend to prevent, obstruct, or affect the sale of any ticket or tickets of any English state lottery now in being, or hereafter to be erected.

XLI. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any justice of the peace, or any other justices herein before described, or mayor, or other chief magistrate of any city or town corporate, shall neglect or refufo to do what is required ot him and them by this act, such mayor, chief magistrate, and justices, so neglecting or refilling, shall respectively forfeit and pay the sum of one hundred pounds for every such offence.

CHAP. VI.

An Act for the Relief of His Majests faithful Subjects the Protestant Biff enters of this Kingdom; and to Repeal a ClauJ'e in the AS of the Second of Queen Anne, entitled, An Act to prevent the further Growth of Popery, as far as the fame relates to the Protefant Disfenters.

WHEREAS by an act made in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne, ended, An act to prevent the further growth of popery, it is amongst other things enacted, That all and every person and persons, that shall be admitted, entered, placed, or taken into any office or offices civil or military, or shall receive any pay, salary, fee, or wages belonging to or by reason of any office or place of trust by reason of any patent or grant from her Majesty, or shall have any command or place of trust from or under her Majesty, or any of her predecessors or successors, or by her or their authority, or by any authority derived from her or them within this realm of Ireland, shall receive the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper according to the usage of the church of Ireland within three months after his or their admittance into or receiving their said authority and employments in some publick church upon the Lord’s day, commonly called Sunday, immediately after divine service and sermon: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every person or persons being piotellants shall and may have, hold, and enjoy any office or offices civil or military, and receive any pay, salary, fee, or wages belonging to or by reason of such office of place, notwithstanding he shall not receive or have received the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, as in the said recited clause is prescribed, without incurring any of the penalties in said act, or any other act enacted for or in respect of his neglect of receiving the lame.

protestant schoois will be of great benefit to this kingdom, and it is tea* sonable, that some publick fund should be applied and let apart for that purpose: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty until the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty two, there shall be answered and paid unto his Majesty, his heirs and successors, by every hawker, rpedlar, petty chapman, or other trading person or persons going from town to town, or to other mens houses, fairs, marts, or markets, and travelling either i>n foot or with horse, horses, or otherwise, in this kingdom (except as herein after mentioned) and carrying to fell or exposing to falc, any goods, wares, or merchandizes (except as herein after mentioned) a duty of twenty shillings by the year; and that every person so travelling with any horse or horses, afs or asses, mule or mules, or any other bead or beasts hearing or drawing burthen, shall pay the sum of twenty shillings by the year, from the twenty fifth day of March, one thousand seven hundred and eighty to the twenty fifth day of March one thousand seven hundred and eighty two, for each horse, afs, or mule, or other bead bearing or drawing burthen, he or she shall so travel with, over and above the said first mentioned duty of twenty shillings by the year; III. And that the quarters both of officers and soldiers in this kingdom may hereafter be duly paid and satisfied, his Majesty's duties of excise better answered, and that the owners of houses, on whom soldiers and officers shall be billetted, may be encouraged to provide good and proper accommodation for such officers, soldiers, and their horses, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid,- that except during such times as the troops shall be on their march, or during such times as there shall be any commotion in any part of this kingdom, or during such times as recruits or recruiting parties remain separated from their regiments and employed in the recruiting service, payment shall be made for each officer and soldier, during the time he or they shall occupy such billet, at the following weekly rates, viz. in Dublin for each field officer and captain eight shillings; for each subaltern officer seven shillings; for each serjeant of dragoons or foot, or corporal of horse, one shilling and one penny; for each trooper, dragoon, or foot soldier, six pence halfpenny; in the country for each field officer or captain five shillings; for each subaltern officer three shillings and six pence; for each serjeant of dragoons or foot, or corporal of horse, one shilling; for each trooper, dragoon, or foot soldier six pence. The payment of the officer’s lodging to be made by the officers themfe’ves in the present accustomed manner. The payment of the men’s lodging to be made monthly by the commanding officer of each corps in each quarter, in consequence of money sent them for that purpose by their several regimental agents; and in order to enable the agents to remit such money such sums shall be advanced to them, asfiiallbeneceflary, for which the regiments shall be accountable, and which sums shall be accounted for in the usual manner; and as an encouragement to provide proper and sufficient (fabling for the horses so billetted, four pence pir week shall he paid to the owners of (fables for each horse, during the time each shall remain, -in such manner and under such circumstances as the quarters of the men are paid,

IV. And as very great detriment and inconvenience arises to the service from the dispersing and billetting of soldiers when on a march at a great distance from the place or places, where they are meant to be quartered, contrary to the true intent and meaning of the said last receited act, and by reason of which they are placed wide of their intended route for the next day’s march: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that at no time, when troops are on a march, shall any of them be billetted above one mile from the place or places mentioned in the route.

V. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That his Majesty's army within this kingdom shall be governed by such articles of war, as have been already or Hull be made by him for the government of all his forces; and that all offences against the same shall be tried and determined by courts martial to be held by virtue of commissions from his Majesty, impowering the lord lieutenant, or other chief governor or governors of this kingdom for the time being, to appoint general courts martial from time to time within the same, as well as to dire# his ot their warrant or warrants to any general officer having the chief command of a body of forces within this kingdom, authorizing him to convene general courts martial, as occasion may require, for the trial of offences committed by any of the forces under his command, such general courts martial to be constituted and their proceedings regulated according to the several provisions, which are or shall be fpt* cified in such articles of war.

XIII. Provided always, That no person or persons shall be adjudged to suffer any punishment extending to life or limb for any offence not at present expressed in such articles.

XX. And for preventing of fraud and deceit in the muttering of soldiers, be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person do make or give, or procure to be made or given, any false or untrue certificate, whereby to excuse any soldier for his absence from any mutter, or any other service which he ought to attend or perform, upon pretence of being employed upon some other duty of the regiment, or of sickness, being in prison, or on furlough, then every fitch person so making, giving, or procuring such certificate, shall for every such offence forfeit the sum of fifty pounds, and shall be forthwith cashiered and displaced from his office, and shall be thereby utterly disabled to have or hold any military office or employment within this realm; and no certificate shall excuse the absence of any soldier but for the reasons above mentioned, or one of them; and the commissary of the mutters is hereby directed to set down on the roll at the time of taking the mutter the reason of the absence of such soldier respectively, and by whom certified, and not to set down any such excuse without view of such certificate.

And whereas it may be expedient in certain cases; and particularly in such matters wherein any of his Majesty's marine forces may be interested, that officers of the marines shall be associated with officers of the land forces for the purpose of holding courts martial: be it enacted and declared by the authority aforesaid, that, when and as often as it may be necessary it shall and may be lawful for the officers of the land and marine forces to fit in conjunction upon courts martial, and to proceed of land and_in the trial of any officer or soldier of the land forces in like co^naion'" manner to all intents and purposes, as if such courts martial were composed of officers of the land forces only, and the officers of to rank by the land and marine forces are in such cases to take rank according fcmoM>-to the seniority of their commissions in either service.

XLVII. And in order to prevent all doubts, that may arise in relation to punishing crimes and offences committed against any articles of war heretofore made by his Majesty for the government of his forces, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that all crimes and offences, which have been committed against any articles of war heretofore made by his Majesty, shall against mi-and may be inquired of, heard, tried, and determined, adjudged and punished, before and by the like courts, persons, powers, tried and authorities, ways, means, and methods, as the like crimes and the offences, committed against the present articles of war made by P«sent-his Majesty, may be inquired of, heard, tried, determined, adjudged, and punished.

III. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that every such deputy or substitute shall be appointed by some authority under the hand and seal of his Majesty's alnager; and that every such deputy or substitute shall be obliged to give security to the said alnager for his conduct in the sum of fifty pounds at the least, to the amount of which sum the said alnager shall be answerable for his said deputy or substitute in case of insolvency, or of his not paying any fines imposed or damages to be recovered in consequence of any misconduct or neglect in his said office, or in consequence of this or any other act relating to the said manufacture.

CHAP. XXIII.

An Act for regulating and extending the Tobacco Trade.

Exbired 25

Dec *1781.

WHEREAS tobacco is subject upon import into this kingdom to the duties following, that is to say, two pence half penny per pound hereditary dudes, and three pence halfpenny par.pound additional duty, and will from and after the twenty fourth day - of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty, be subject to a further additional duty of one penny and sixty three . one hundred parts of one penny per pound, making in the whole seven pence aifd sixty three one hundred parts of one penny per pound, with the usual allowances or discounts out of said hereditary duties and first additional duty: and whereas it may tend much to the encouragement of the tobacco trade, if importers thereof be allowed time for payment of part of the duties in manner herein after mentioned: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords fpmtual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That it shall and may be lawful to and for every person, importing tobacco into this kingdom between the twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty, and the twenty fifth day of December, one thousand seven hundred and eighty one indufive, in lieu of paying down the said several duties with their discounts (if such person shall so desire) to pay and secure upon importation thereof the sums following, that is to say, every such person shall pay down in rcadv money upon import a net duty after the rate of five pounds nineteen shillings and eighteen twentieth parts of one penny and one half of a twentieth for every one hundred pounds value of such tobacco, as the fame is rated for excise in this kingdom, and shall also become bound to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, with on-or more sufficient sureties, to be approved of by the collector of the port where the tobacco shall be imported, With the consent of the surveyor of such port, in one or more bond or bonds, at the election of the importer, for the payment of a further duty, after the

The nineteenth and twentieth Years of George III. 571

the rate of thirty three pounds fifteen shillings and three pence fir twentieth parts A.D. of one penny, two thirds of one twentieth, for the said quantity of tobacco, I 779-80. within eighteen months, the said eighteen months to commence at the end of thirty days after the mailer’s report of the ship, or to commence from the merchant’s entry of the goods within said thirty days, which ever shall first happen.

II. Provided always, That any person not being a native of Great Britain or Ireland, who shall import tobacco, shall pay after the rate of seven pounds feveit shillings and firpence three twentieth parts of onepenny, and one third part of a twentieth, in lieu of the rate aforesaid, of five pounds nineteen shillings and eighteen twentieth parts of one penny and one half of a twentieth.

III. Provided always, and in as much as several merchants and others importing tobaccos may be frequently under difficulties, and unable to give good and sufficient securities for the payment of the said duty herein allowed to be secured, and the putting of the fame into proper warehouses may not only be an ease and convenience to the importer thereof, but also a security to his Majesty's revenue: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the said twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty, any person importing tobacco, who shall hive paid down in ready money a net duty for the fame after the rate of five pounds nineteen shillings and eighteen twentieth parts of one penny and one half of a twentieth, or of seven pounds seven shillings and futpence three twentieth parts of a penny and one third part of a twentieth, for every 011c hundred pounds value thereof according to the rate aforesaid, and shall then desire to have the said tobacco put into warehouses under the King’s and merchant’s locks for the security of the remainder of the duties, the merchant or merchants, or his or their ferrants shall have free access into the said warehouses at all seasonable times, and the custom house officers are hereby required to attend without fee or reward; and it shall and may be lawful for the commissioners or principal officers of his Majesty's revenue to permit and cause the said tobacco to be lodged and put into warehouses to be provided by and at the charge of the merchant or merchants, and to be first approved by the said commissioners or officers, upon the merchant or merchants giving his or their own bond for payment of the duties at the end of fifteen months; and if the importer or importers of fitch tobacco, as has been so lodged in the w'archouses, shall not within the said time of fifteen months offer good and sufficient security for payment of the duties at the end of the said eighteen months, or by debentures on cx-

IV. V. And whereas great frauds an ay arise to the diminution of lus Majesty's revenue by warehousing tobacco as aforesaid in ports, where there are or shall not be a sufficient number of revenue officers to attend the fame: be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fifth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty, that it shall and niav be lawful for the commissioners of his Majesty's revenue, or any four of them, from time to time, and as often as they shall see occasion> to prohibit, for such time as they shall think proper, by notice under their hands, which notice shall be published in the ga2ette, and some other publick news paper, ami be likewise sent to the chief officer of the port or ports therein mentioned, any tobacco imported at any port to be mentioned in such notice, except the port of Dublin, Drogheda, Dundalk, Newry, Belfast, Derry, GaUvay, Limerick, Cork, "Waterford, Wexford, and Wicklow, ro be warehoused; and that from and after such notice during the time therein mentioned, no importer of tobacco at any such port shall desire the same to be lodged in a ware-

VI. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case any tobacco, which shall have been entered, and the duties thereof paid,or partlypaid and partlyfecured in manner aforesaid, shall from and after the said twenty fourth dayof June,one thousand seven hundred and eighty, be exported from this kingdom, the exporter shall upon the exportation thereof within three years, on a proper debenture to be made forth for that purpose, be paid or allowed to draw back the whole net duty actually paid by him on the import thereof, and to have the security vacated on the bond or bonds given on the importation, and no more, as to what shall be so exported; any law or custom to the contrary notwithstanding.

VII. Provided always, That no drawback shall be given after the twenty fifth day of December, one thousand seven hundred and eighty one, of any duties paid on tobacco imported previous to the twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty.

IX. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty, all bonds to be given for securing the duties by virtue of this act shall be deemed and taken to be due and payable immediately upon the day mentioned in the condition of the said bond for the payment thereof j and that the legal interest shall be paid to the crown on all such bonds*, such interest be computed from the day the bond becomes due unto the day whereon it shall be paid off in money, or the day the fcarcher certifies upon the debenture, that the tobacco was shipped for exportation, notwithstanding such tobacco doth or shall remain unexported, and the three years being the time limited by law for the drawback on exportation shall not be expired, and no such security shall be vacated, until all such interest shall be paid thereon.

IX. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty, all bonds to be given for securing the duties by virtue of this act shall be deemed and taken to be due and payable immediately upon the day mentioned in the condition of the said bond for the payment thereof; and that the legal intcrell shall be paid to the crown on all such bonds; such intcrell be computed from the day the bond becomes due unto the day whereon it shall be paid off in money, or the day the searcher certifies upon the debenture, that the tobacco was shipped for exportation, notwithstanding such tobacco doth or shall remain unexported, and the three years being the time limited by law for the drawback on exportation shall not be expired, and no such security shall be vacated, until all such filtered shall be paid thereon.

no tobacco, either manufactured or unmanufactured, shall be entered or shipped for exportation to any parts beyond the fcas, Great Britain only excepted, in any ship or vessel whatsoever, unless such ship or vessel shall be of the burthen of seventy tons or upwards; and if any officer or officers of the revenue shall apprehend, or have reason to believe, that any such ship or vessel bound to foreign parts, and tobacco on board her, shall not be of the burthen of seventy' tons and upwards, it shall and may be lawful for such officer or officers to (lop and detain such ship or vessel, and the whole cargo laden on board her, and all other goods, until he or they shall cause such ship or vessel to be admeasured in manner herein after mentioned; and if it shall appear by such admeasurement, that any ship or vessel is of the bur, then of seventy tons or upwards, the officer or officers, so (topping and detaining her and her cargo, shall not be subject or liable to any action for damages occasioned by such Itoppage and detention; and if the matter or commander of any ship or vessel outward bound to foreign parts, having tobacco on board her, shall enter and clear out such ship or other vessel in the collector's books at the custom house as of the burthen of seventy tons or upwards, and such ship or vessel shall not be of so great burthen according to the admeasurement prescribed, he shall forfeit and lose the sum of one hundred pounds for every such offence.

XXXIa And for preventing disputes concerning the admeasurement of such ships or vessels, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the following rule shall be observed therein j that is to say, the length shall be taken on a (traight line along the rabbet of the keel of the ship from the back of the main (tern port to a perpen. dicular line from the fote part of the main (tern under the bowsprit, from which fubllradting three fifths of the breadth, the remainder shall be esteemed the just length of the keel to find the tonnage t and the breadth shall be taken from the outside of the outside plank in the broadelt place of the ship, be it cither above or below the main whales, exclusive of all manner of doubling planks that may be wrought upon the fides of the ship, then multiplying the length of the keel by the breadth so taken, and that product by half the breadth, and dividing the whole by ninety four, the quotient shall be deemed the true contents of the tonage; accord, ing to which rule the tonage of all such ships and vessels shall be measured and ascertained; any law, custom, or usage to the contrary notwithstanding.

An Act for the Relief of Persons twbo have omitted to Qualify them* /elves.according to Lam*

WHEREAS several persons, well a Hefted, to his Majesty's government, and the church of Ireland, ashy law established, may have through ignorance negteft-. ed,or been prevented by(ickness,or other unavoidable causes, from taking and subscribing the oaths, and making, repeating, and subscribing the declaration, and from receiving the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, and delivering a certificate thereof, accord-. ing to- the directions of an act made in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne, entitled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery, and may thereby have incurred great penalties: be it therefore enacted by the icing’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consentof the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every person and persons, who have incurred any penalties, and, incapacities in the said act, entitled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery, ;mentioned, by neglecting to qualify themselves according to the said act, ;shall be and are hereby indemnified, freed, and discharged-of and from all incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, and penalties, incurred byreason of such omission . or neglect as aforesaid; and that no act or acts done by them, or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be questioned or avoided by xeafou of such neglect or omission.; but all such acts shall be, and are hereby declared and enacted to be, as good and effectual, as if all and every such person and persons had taken and sub-.feribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and delivered a certificate thereof, and made, repeated, and subscribed the said declaration, at such time, place, and manner as is therein mentioned; any thing in the said act to the contrary not* with Handing.

II. Provided always, That such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the - ;said catlis, and make, repeat, and subscribe the said declaration, in such manner and form, and in such place and places, as are directed and appointed by the said act to prevent the further growth of popery, bn or before the twenty fourth day of ' June, which will be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and eighty one.

III. And whereas several of his Majesty's subjects are often preferred in the army, While they are redding in Great Britain, whereupon they are by the laws in force in that kingdom obliged to qualify themselves in some part of Great Britain by receiving the sacrament, taking the oaths, and subscribing the declaration thereby required, within the time mentioned in such law’s: and whereas the regiment or regiments, in which such officer or officers have commissions ib granted to them, are often ordered into this kingdom, and put upon this establishment, by which a doubt has arisen, whether such officer or officers, notwithstanding his or their having ..qualified themselves in Great Britain for such commission according to the said laws, are not by the said laws in force in this kingdom obliged to qualify them-ielves after their arrival here for such commissions according to an act of Parliament, passed in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty -queen Anne, entitled, An act to prevent the further greioth of popery: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, ‘That no officer or officers so preferred in Great Britain, who shall have-qualified -him or themselves for such commission or commissions according to and within the limited time by the fiud laws made in Great Britain shall be obliged to qualify him or themselves in this kingdom for such commission or commissions-so granted to him or them in such regiment or regiments after their arrival in this kingdom, and being put upon this establiflmicnt} any law, uf.ige, or.cu(lom,.to the contrary notwithstanding.

IV.
