An ASfor naturalizing such Foreign Merchants, Traders, Art's-ficers. Artisans, Manufacturers, Worhnen, Seamen, Farmers, and others, as shall settle in this Kingdom.

WHEREAS the increase of people is a means of advancing the wealth and strength of any nation: and whereas many foreigners and strangers from the lenity of our government, the benefit of our laws, the advantages of our trade, the security of our property, and from the consideration of the plen-tifulness of all forts of useful and profitable commodities with which this your Majesty's kingdom of Ireland abounds, might be induced to settle in this kingdom, if they were made partakers of the advantages and privileges, which the natural born subjects of this realm do enjoy: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, From ift and by the authority of the same, That from and after the first day of September next, all foreign merchants, traders, artificers, y*10

CHAP. XXX.

An act for the relief of tenants bolding under leases for lives containing covenants for perpetual renewals.

WHEREAS great parts of the lands in this kingdom are

held under leases for lives with covenants for perpetual under leases renewals upon payment of certain fines at the times therein relpec- uewable on lively mentioned for each renewal: and whereas from' various ac- j?Jcotof cidents and causes such tenants, and those deriving under them, ’ have frequently neglected, to pay or tender such fines within the neglect of times prescribed by such covenants after the fall of such fives respectivety; and whereas many such leases are settled to make within the provision for families and creditors, most of whom must be t'me'’ utterly ruined, if advantage shall be taken of such neglects, which will occasion much confusion and distress in the kingdom:

6io

A.D.

779.80. Chap. 30.

that such intefefts may not be defeated by mere neglect where no fraud* on making full satisfaction*

courts of equity on adequate compensation shall relieve such tenants andafligns against such lapfc, if no fraud proved*

unless demand of fines proved* and refusal or neglect to pay in reasonable time after.

If difficult to discover tenant or assignee, demand on the lands from principal occupier with 2 months notice in Gazettes a demand within this act.

Not to affect judgment or decree given* orfuit before 15 May 1780* and now depending.

f be nineteenth and twentieth years of George III.

arid whereas it has been for a long time a received opinion in this kingdom, to which some decilions in courts of equity and declarations of judges have given countenance, that courts of equity would in such cases relieve against the lapse of time upon giving an adequate compensation to the persons, to whom such fines were payable, or their representatives: and to the end that such interests may not be defeated by a mere neglect, where no fraud appears to have been intended, upon making full satisfaction to the Mors, or those deriving under them; be it declared and enacted by the king’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that courts of equity upon an adequate compensation being made shall relieve such tenants and their assigns against such lapse of time, if no circumstance of fraud be proved against such tenants or their assigns; unless it shall be proved to the satisfaction of such courts, that the landlords orleflors, or persons entitled to receive such fines, had demanded such fines from such tenants or their assigns, and that the fame had been refused or neglected to be paid within a reasonable time after such demand.

II. Provided atways, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that in case the landlord shall find any difficulty in discovering his tenant or the assignee of such tenant, io as to make a demand on such tenant or assignee, that then and in every such case a demand made of the said fine on the lands from the principal occupier of the fame together with a notice of such demand, to be inserted for the space of two months in the London and Dublin Gazettes, shall be considered to all intents and purposes a demand within this act.

III. Provided always, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that nothing herein contained shall in any fort affect any judgment or decree already given or made, or any suit commenced before the fifteenth day of May one thousand seven hundred and eighty, and now depending for the recovery of the possession of any manors, messuages, lands, tenements, or hereditaments on account of any lease or leases not having been renewed according to the covenants for perpetual renewals therein contained.

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, i that if any person or persons shall at any time or times hereafter sell or expose to sale any share or chance of any ticket in such lottery or lotteries as aforesaid, without such share or chance shall have been first stamped and marked by the said officer or officers pursuant to this act, that then and in such case every such person and persons so offending shall forfeit and pay the sum of one hundred pounds for each and every share or chance so fold

or exposed to sale as aforesaid.

XX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any person or persons shall forge or counterfeit or canfe or procure to be forged or counterfeited, or shall willingly act or assist in the forging or counterfeiting, any receipt or receipts for any share or shares, chance or chances, of any ticket or tickets, signed, divided, made and delivered out by virtue of this act, or alter any number, figure, word, or stamp therein or thereon, or utter, vend, barter, or dispose of any such forged, counterfeited, or altered receipt or receipts for any share or shares, chance or chances, of any ticket or tickets, or shall bring any such forged or counterfeited receipt or receipts, or any share or shares, chance or chances, the (lamp whereof or any figure or word therein shall have been altered (knowing the same to be such) to any person or persons with a fraudulent intention, or shall willingly aid, abet, assist, hire, or command any person or persons to commit any such offence as aforesaid, then and in every such case all and every such person or persons so offending shall be deemed a felon and felons, and shall suffer death without benefit of clergy.

XXI. An act for amending and explaining the feverdl laws made in this kingdom for carrying on the Lagan navigation.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the twenty seventh year of the reign of his late Majesty' king George the second of glorious memory certain duties, rates, and impositions were granted to his laid late Majesty, his heirs and successors, for a certain term therein specified, (to wit) an additional duty of acife of one penny by the gallon over and above the duties then payable to his Majesty upon every gallon of beer or ale that was above the price of six shillings each barrel, brewed within that part of the district of Lilburn, commonly known and distinguished by the Gauger's walks of Belfast, Lilburn, Moira, and Hillsborough, by the common brewer, or in his vessels, or by any person or persons who should vend the fame by retail, to be paid by such common brewer, or by such other person or persons who should brew the same to fell by retail, as also one penny additional duty on every gallon of the like beer and ale which should be brewed in any other walk or district, and which should be brought into the said walks 'or any of them for falc, the said additional duties to be paid by the person or persons who should io bring in and vend the fame; and also an additional duty of four pence by the gallon, and proportionably for any lesser quantity, over and above the duties of excise before payable to his Majesty on every gallon of aquavita, strong waters, spirits, made or distilled within the said walks for sale, or that should be made or distilled in any other part of this kingdom and brought into the said walks or any of them to be therein vended by retail: and it was provided by the said act, that such additional duties should be repaid, in case any beer, ale, aquevita, strong waters, or spirits, for which the said additional duties should or ought to be paid as aforesaid, should be within twelve months, alter the said additional duties should be so paid, exported out of this kingdom, or carried out of the said walks to any other part of this kingdom; II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall and may be lawful to and for the said company from time to time, as occasion shall require, to assemble in the town of Belfast, or in the towns of Lilburn, Hillsborough, Moira, or Lur-gan, or in any of them, and from time to time to adjourn such assemblies, and at such assemblies or adjournments thereof to make such bye-laws or orders for the better government of their affairs and of their members, and for making such contracts ami agreements, and ascertaining the tolls and lockage to be paid on the said navigation, and for appointing such servants and persons for carrying on the said navigation, as they shall think fit; and to vary or repeal such bye laws, rules, and orders, and to make new ones for the good and orderly using of the said navigation, and for settling the wages, and for the well governing the bargemen, watermen, and boatmen, who shall convey any goods thereon, ami to inipose reasonable fines and forfeitures upon all persons offending therein, the said fines and forfeitures to be levied by such ways and means as the company shall direct, so as no such fine shall exceed five pounds upon any person for one offence; and the said bye-laws being put into writing under the seal of the said company shall be binding on and observed by all panics, and shall be sufficient in any court of law or equity to justify all persons, who shall act under the fame, or in levying any penalty or forfeiture thereby inclined.

The nineteenth and twentieth years of George III.

III. Provided always, that the said bye-laws shall not be contrary to the laws and statutes of this realm, but shall be approved of by the lord high chancellor of Ireland for the time, being, the lord chief justice of the king’s bench for the time bong, the lord chief justice of the common pleas for the time being, and the lord chief baron of the court of exchequer for the time being, or any two of them.

IV. Provided always, that eight days notice at the least, including the day of such notice and the day of meeting, previous to such meeting, shall be given of the time and place of holding such alTemblies for making bye laws in the Belfast News Letter, or in such other publick newspaper as shall be agreed on by the said company.

V. Provided nevertheless, that any person, who shall think himself aggrieved by any order or judgment in pursuance of any such bye law, may complain withoin six months thence after to the justices at the quarter sessions in the county, wherein such bye laws shall be carried into execution, who shall in a-summary way hear and determine the said complaint at such quarter sessions; and, if they fee cause, may mitigate or alter such fines or forfeitures, and may order any money to be returned, which shall have been levied or paid in pursuance of such bye laws, and may also order such further satisfaction to be made, and give such costs to the party injured, as they shall judge reafo-nable.

VI. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the several sums of money heretofore subscribed or paid pursuant to the said recited acts of parliament, or any of them, together with all such sums of money as shall by virtue of and under this act be advanced and paid for the carrying on the said navigation, shall be deemed, taken, and considered to all intents and purposes as the joint stock of the said company.

XXIII. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall and may be lawful to and for every subscriber under the said former acts, or any of them, and every other person who shall advance or pay any sum of money under and by virtue of this act towards compleating the said work, and through whose lands or estate the said navigation or any part thereof now doth or hereafter may pass and be carried, to charge his real estate for the use of his younger child or children with the payment of such sum and sums of money and other interest, which he may have in the said joint stock, as he shall assign or bequeath to his heir, any settlement or any law, usage, or custom to the contrary notwithstanding; it being judged most fit and proper that the proprietors of estates, through which the said navigation does or shall pass, should have a property and interest therein.

XXIV. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall and may be lawful for the said company to erect one or more turnpikes upon and across any of the trackways, which now are or shall be made on either fide of the said navigation, and to take and receive the following tolls, for which they may distrain and fell, as is usual at other turnpikes; (that is to say) for every coach, berlin, choriot, or chaise, drawn by fix horles, one shilling: for every coach, berlin, chariot, or chaise, drawn by 'less than fixhorfes, and more than one, sixpence; for every waggon two shillings and sixpence; for every cart or other carriage with four wheels sixpence; for every chaise with one horse threepence; for every car or cart with more than one horse twopence; for every car or cart with one horse one penny; for every single horse one penny; for every drove of oxen, cows, or neat cattle twenty pence by the score; and for every drove of calves, hogs, sheep, goats, or lambs ten pence by the score, and so in proportion for any greater or Idler number.

XXV. Provided always, that such toll shall be paid only once at one gate in any one day; and that no road, which is now publick, shall be thereby obstructed.

The nineteenth and twentieth years of George III.

XXVI. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the owner of every vessel or boat above the burthen of two tons navigating the said canal or navigation, or any of the off branches thereof, shall cause his, her, or their names and places of abode, and also the name of the person having the care of such vessel or boat, and his place of abode, with the dimensions or tunnage of their respective boats or vessels, to be painted in large capital letters on the upper part of the quarter on each side of such vessel or boat, and to be kept constantly legible upon the lame j and shall cause the fame several particulars to be entered in a book kept by said company for that purpose; and shall also cause the said boat to be numbered as aforesaid; or in default thereof every such owner shall forfeit the sum of forty shillings, to be recovered by any person who will sue for the same.

XXVII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the owner of every such boat or vessel navigating the said canal, or any of the off branches thereof, shall be answerable for any damage or mischief, which shall be done by any of the crew or persons belonging to any such boat or vessel to any of the works of the said navigation, or to any of the goods laden in such boat or vessel.

XXVIII. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any person having the charge or management of any boat or other vessel, or navigating or working the fame, shall lay such boat or vessel so as to obstruct the passage of other boats or vef-(cls, and shall not upon request immediately remove the fame, or shall hinder the opening or (hutting of any of the locks, sluices, dams, or other works of the said navigation, or if the person having the care or management of such vessel shall be absent (unless by reason of some inevitable accident) from the boat or vessel, to which he belongs, at any time during (he course of the passage on the said canal, cuts, or river, every person so offending shall for every such offence forfeit any sum not exceeding fwtv shillings.

XXIX. IX. And whereas it would tend much to the enlargement of the linen and hempen manufactures^ if various branches thereof were to be encouraged by a bounty on their exportation: bs it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that every person or persons, who shall export out of this kingdom to Africa, America, Spain, Portugal, Gibraltar, or the island of Minorca, at any time or times between the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and eighty and the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and eighty one inclusive, any Irish linens made of flax or hemp of the breadth of twenty five inches or more, shall receive without fee or reward the bounties following, that is to say, for every yard thereof under the value of five pence the sum of one halfpenny; and for every yard thereof of the value of five pence, and under the value of six pence halfpenny, the sum of one penny; and for every yard thereof of the value of six pence halfpenny, and under the value of one shilling and seven pence halfpenny, the sum of three halfpence; and that every person or persons, who shall export to any of the said places during the time aforesaid any Irish chequed or striped linen of the breadth of twenty five inches or more, or any Irish made diapers, huckabacks, sheeting, or other pieces of linen upwards of one yard in breadth, shall receive without fee or reward the bounties following, that is to say, for every yard of such chequed or striped linen not exceeding one shilling and seven pence halfpenny, and not under seven pence the yard in value, the sum of one halfpenny; and for every square yard of such diaper, huckaback, sheeting, or other linens, upwards of one yard in breadth, and not exceeding one shilling and seven pence halfpenny the square yard in value, the sum of three halfpence for every square yard thereof, and so in proportion for any quantity exceeding a square yard; and that every person or persons, who shall export during the time aforesaid to any place except Great Britain any Irish made sail cloth or canvas, fit for or made into fails, by way of merchandize, shall receive without fee or deduction a bounty of six pence halfpenny for every three ells thereof.

An Act for regulating the Sugar Trade, and granting to His Majesty. His Heirs and Successors, the Duties therein mentioned.

Kxpirej25^ ^nrrE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects the commons of Ireland, in Parliament assembled, as a further supply to your Majesty to support the expences of your Majesty's government and with a grateful sense of the large and commercial benefits to arise from an open and direct intercourse with the sugar colonics of Great Britain, do most humbly bcfeedi your Majesty, tint it may be enacted, and be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and tern-poral and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the twenty fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty, until the twenty fifth day of December, one thousand seven hundred and eighty one inclusive, and no longer, there shall he raised, levied, collected, and paid unto your Majesty, your heirs and successors, the several rates ami duties herein after mentioned; that is to say, an additional duty for and upon all brown or Muscovado sugars, being of the growth or produce of the British plantations in America or the West Indies, after the rate of sixteen pounds one Hulling and eleven pence and fifteen twentieth parts of a penny for every one hundred pound? value thereof, as the fame is rated for custom in this kingdom, which shall be imported during the time aforesaid from any of the said places by any of his Majesty’.*

III. An Act for the Relief of Persons in aBual Custody for Debt.

-whose names are mentioned in the schedule hereunto annexed, against whom no petition hath been preferred to the house of commons of -this kingdom during this session of Parliament at any time before the first day of May, one thousand seven hundred and eighty two, to exhibit petitions to his Majesty 6 court of King's bench or common pleas in Dublin, setting forth the several matters directed to be set forth in the petitions of the persons mentioned in a schedule annexed to an act passed in the first year of his present Majesty, entitled, An act for the ivlief cf in-fshent debtors; and the said several persons shall, upon performing the several requires in the said act directed to be performed by the several persons mentioned in the schedule thereunto annexed, be entitled to the -like benefit and relief, and subject to the like punishment in case-of delivering a false and untrue account of their estate and effects, or concealing the fame, as by the said alt is directed with respect to the several persons, whufe names are-mentioned in the said schedule annexed to the said acts and the respective-dhtes and effects of the persons, whose names are mentioned in the schedule hereunto annexed, shall be subject to all and Angular the terms and proviGons mentioned in the said act with respect to the eftntes and effects of the persons, whose names are mentioned in the said schedule annexed to the-find alt.

V. And whereas several persons discharged from prison under the former acts of insolvency, and who performed the requilites required to be performed by such alts, have been afterwards contrary to the good intention and true meaning of such acts arrested and continued in prison at the suit or suits of their former creditors, in order that by such confinement the unhappy debtors might during the vacation of term fuller the cruelty of such confinement, and undergo the difficulties of inffituting a suit to recover that liberty, which it was the humane intention of such acts to have given them without any such difficulties: therefore be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any of the persons in the annexed schedule, who shall be discharged from their confinement by conforming him, her, or themselves truly and honestly to the intent and meaning of this act, and who have' performed the requilites required to be performed without any fraud or perjury, shall be thereafter arrested and confined, or have any suit or suits whatsoever commenced against him, her, or them by reason of any judgment or decree, or for any debt, damages, attachments, contempts, colls, sum or sums of money contrasted, incurred, occasioned, owing, or growing due before the time of such persons taking the benefit of and being discharged by this act; and then and in such case or cases the creditor or creditors respectively, at whose suit such person or persons hath, or have been so arrested or imprisoned, or hath or have any such suit or suits so commenced against him, her, or them, shall forfeit the sum of twenty pounds tteriing, to be paid to the said person or persons so arrested, confined or proceeded against, and which sum or sums shall be recovered with treble costs by civil bill In such court or courts, where proceedings by civil bill may by law be had, or by action of debt, plaint, or information in any of his Majesty's courts of record in Dublin, in which no protection, waget of law, or essoign shall be allowed, or more than one imparlance.

VI. - Provided, That nothing herein contained shall extend to protect the real or personal property of any person obtaining benefit under this act: but the fame ate hereby declared liable to all demands of every creditor of such person, any tiling herein contained to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding.

VII. Provided always, That no person shall take or have any benefit by this aO, whohas made any fraudulent conveyance or assignment of his estate and goods, or any part thereof, either previous or subsequent to his failure, with an intention to defraud his creditors, or any of them, or who has done, or fullered to be done, any fraudulent act for the purpose aforesaid, and the same shall be made to appear to the satisfaction of the court, in which the petition of such debtor shall be depending, upon an examination either viva voce, or by affidavit, as such court shall direct.

VIII. And provided always, That nothing herein contained shall extend or be construed to extend, to the benefit of any person, who is within the provisions oi the bankruptcy law.

IX. And provided always, That nothing herein contained shall extend or be construed to extend to the benefit of any person, who has been relieved by, and taken,the benefit of any former act of insolvency.

X. And provided always, That no person as guardian, trustee, executor, or administrator, is indebted to any person or persons, or who either now is or shall be hereafter committed by virtue of any attachment or serjeant at arms for a contempt of any court of justice in not accounting for or paying any sum or sums of nto-

XI. Provided also, That all persons, who have conveyed, embezzled, or converted \ to their own use, any monies, goods, wares, or merchandizes of persons, who have employed or intruded them, or who have made use of any fraud, false token or pretence for obtaining any sum of money, shall be excluded from receiving any benefit or advantage by this act.

XII. Provided always, That nothing herein contained shall extend or be deemed to extend, or shall in any manner be construed or taken to extend, to give benefit, ease, discharge, or relief to any person or persons whatsoever for any debt for rent or arrears of rent, whether by a bond, note, or other settlement, in writing, per* felted to the landlord or landlords for the fame, or otherwise, which debt became due and payable out of any lands, tenements, and hereditaments, when he, (lie, or they owing such rent or arrears of rent, or any other person or persons deriving by, from, or under him, her, or them, is or are in possession of all or any such lands, tenements, or hereditaments, out of which such rent was payable.

XIII. Provided likewise, That this act shall not extend to free the real or per* forial estate of any person obtaining benefit under this act, which such person or persons shall acquire or become entitled to after having taken the benefit thereof* but that the same shall be liable to the debts owing by them in as full and ample a manner, as if this act had never been made.

CHAP. XLI.

An Act for empowering Grand furies to present Bridges and Tolls to be paid for passing the fame in certain cases.

WHEREAS the building and erecting good and sufficient bridges over divers rivers and waters in this kingdom would prove of the greatest utility by promoting and facilitating the pa (Page of goods, merchandizes, cattle, carriages, and travellers from one part to another, and thereby extending that free and uninterrupted communication which is always highly beneficial and necessary in a commercial country: and whereas grand juries, who, as the law now Hands, have power to present sufficient films of money for eroding bridges, where they may think them necessary, are often induced to decline presenting the moll necessary bridges on account of the expence attending the lame, and to avoid loading the people with heavy taxes, whom they' may think already fufliciemly charged for other county ptirpolcs: and whereas private persons may often be induced to take upon themselves the risque, labour, and expence of erecting and maintaining fitch bridge or bridges from time to time without any eels on any county, if they should be by law allowed a rcaibnable toll for all persons, cattle, and carriages passing the fame: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the first day of August one thousand seven hundred and eighty every grand jury of any comity, or county of a city or county of a town, at any , assizes to be holden for the fame may receive from any person or persons, willing to build any bridge or bridges over any river or water in such county, or county of a city or county of a town, any proposal or proposals for building such bridge or bridges without any expence to such county, or county of a city or county of a town, and the plan or plans of the fame, with a " 3 11,11

VIII. And whereas by the said recited act of the seventeenth and eighteenth years of the reign of his present Majesty the said roads leading from the town of Navan to the town of Nobber, and from the said town of Navan to the said town of Kells, in the laid

The nineteenth and twentieth years of George III.

said last and in the said several other former recited acts particularly mentioned, were discontined, and have ever since ceased to be deemed, taken, or tonfidered as publick turnpike roads in any manner whatsoever; and it being now thought expedient and adviseable for the more effectually carrying into execution the several purposes and intentions of the said several former recited acts and of this present act, that the said road, as herein before particularly described, leading from the city of Dublin to the town of Navan, should be made into two divisions: therefore be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said road leading as aforesaid from the city of Dublin to the town of Navan shall be divided into two parts or districts, as follows, that is to say, that so much of the said road, as reaches from Stoncybatter aforesaid to the Black Bull Inn adjoining the turn of the road to Trim, shall hereafter be known and dif-tinjuished by the name of the southern division of the said road; and so much thereof, as reaches from the Black Bull Inn aforesaid, in and to the town of Navan, shall hereafter be distinguislted and known by the name of the northern division of the said road.

IX. And whereas there is a provisoe in the first receited act pass-cd in the third year of his late Majesty king George the second, that in case there should be more than one gate or turnpike in, cross, or on the fide of the said highway or road between the said city of Dublin and the said town of Navan, no person or persons, who should have paid the toll or duty at the first gate or turnpike, through which such person or persons should pass, and who should produce a note or ticket, that the said toll or duty had been paid, should be liable to pay any toll or duty at any other of the said gates or turnpike upon or on the fide of the said highway or road, who should deliver the said note of ticket to the receiver or receivers, collector or collectors, of the toll or duty at the latter gate or turnpike the fame day: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said clause be repealed, and declared null and void.

XXII. Provided always, That no greater sum than one hundred pounds shall be raised off said county in any one year for the purposes aforesaid, any thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

And in order to remove any doubts relative to applotments made in the several districts in the said county, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall not be lawful for any collectorto demand payment for any county or barony cess without producing the original applotment ligned and fwornto by the appointed applotters, in which shall be specified the several sums, which each person in the parifliordiftriftis applotted to pay; and in case no applotters have been appoint, d, or having been appointed have neglected to make the applotment, the culector fi> il produce the applotment with his own affidavit annexed, as directed by the said act, together with the lull applotment which shall have been made on the parish or dif-irift.

XXV. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any suit shall le commenced against any person or persons for any thing done in pursuance of this act, that in every such case the action or suit shall be commenced within six calendar months, next-after the faftshallbe committed, and not afterwards, and shall be laid in the said county of Dublin, and not elsewhere,; and the defendant or defendants in such action or actions to be brought shall and may plead the general issue, and give this act and the special matter in evidence at any trial to.be had thereupon, and that the fame was done in pursuance and by the authority of this act, and if it shall appear.so to have been done, or that such action or suit was brought after the time before limited, or in any other county or place than in the said county of Dublin, that then the jury shall find for the defendant or defendantsj and upon such verdict, or if the plaintiff shall be nonsuited or discontinue his action, after the defendant or defendants shall have appeated, or if on any demurrer judgment shall be given against the plaintiff, the defendant or defendants shall and may recover treble costs, and have the like remedy for the same as any - defendant or defendants hath or have in other cases by law.

XXVI. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act shall ' be deemed, adjudged, and taken to be a publick act, and be judicially taken notice of as such by all judges, justices, and other persons whatsoever, without Jpecially pleading the same, and shall have continuance and be in force from the first day of the next Michaelmas term after the passing of this act: inclusive until the twenty -secondday.of June which will be in the year of our fordone thousand eight hundred and nineteen, and no longer.

CHAP. XLVI.

An act for making and keeping in repair a road to lead from the town of Nenagb in the county of Tipperary to O'Briens bridge in the county of Clare.

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act shall be deemed, adjudged, and taken to be a publick act, and be judicially taken notice of as such by all judges, justices, and other persons whatsoever without specialljr pleading the same.

The nineteenth and twentieth years of George III. CHAP. L.

An act for farther enforcing a due execution of the lavis relative to turnpike roads in this kingdom.

WHEREAS irtany of the turnpike roads in this kingdom have been for several years past much neglected, and are now greatly out of repair: be it enacted by the king’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that the treasurers of the several turnpike roads in this kingdom respectively shall on or before the first day of October one thousand seven hundred and eighty deposite with the clerks of the peace of the counties respectively, though which the turnpike roads of this kingdom, or any part thereof is or are carried, true copies of all and every lease and leases, articles and agreements, whereby the turnpike gates or tolls of the said roads respectively are now set or agreed to be set, together with a true account of air sums received and paid on account of the said road, down to the day of depofuing the said account, and shall afterwards return to the said clerks of the peace on or before the first day of October in every year copies of every lease, article, and agreement, that shall be made of the said gates or tolls, or of any of them, together with a true account of the sums that shall be received and paid on account of the said road from the time of making the last return, together with the number of perches of the said road which shall have been repaired from the time aforesaid.

II. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that if any treasurer of any turnpike road in this kingdom shall fail to comply with the orders hereby given, or with any of them, or shall hereafter fail to make such returns, as are directed to be made by a statute made in this kingdom in the thirteenth and fourteenth years of the reign of his present Majesty, entitled, An act for enforcing a due execution of the laws relative to turnpike roadt in this kingdom, it shall and may be lawful to and for any one of the justices of assize for the said county to examine upon oath the clerk of the peace touching the said returns, and to fine every treasurer neglecting or omitting to make such returns as aforesaid in any sum not exceeding the sum of twenty pounds, and to order execution against the body, goods, and lands of the said treasurer for the said sum.

The nineteenth and twentieth yeats of Geci'gc lit.

III. Provided always, that no such fine shall be imposed for any neglect, that has happened in not complying with the directions of the said statute of the thirteenth and fourteenth years of his present Majesty at any time before the passing of this act; and that where such fine shall be imposed, there shall be no proceeding for the forfeiture of twenty pounds mentioned in the said last mentioned statute.

IV. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that every such treasurer shall verify upon oath before two magistrates of the county or of one of the counties, through which the said road pafies, which oath the said magistrates are hereby empowered and required to administer, that the said return is a true and just return to the bell of his knowledge and belief; which oath shall be signed by the said treasurer at the foot of the said account, and by the said magistrate.

V. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said clerks of the peace shall carefully keep and preserve the said paper, so to be deposited with them, in their offices respectively; and for every failure or neglect shall be fined by the judge of assize in any sum of money not exceeding twenty pounds, and shall be ordered into execution for the said sum.

VI. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, that it shall and may be lawful to and for the grand jury of every county to call every such treasurer before them, and to examine him upon oath, first fending him to one of the judges to be fwoni, touching the Hate of the said road, and all matters whatsoever relative to the tolls, rents, debts, and credits of the fame; and if it shall appear to the said grand jury by an affidavit to be l’worn before one of the judges of assize for the said county, that any part of the said road is in had repair or condition, and that the money remaining in the treasurer's hands is sufficient for repairing the said part of the said road, or that the rents relcrved for the said tolls will be sufficient for repairing the fame within a certain time, to be ascertained by the said grand jury, that in every such case it shall and may be lawful to and for the said grand jury to make a presentment, that the said treasurer shall within a certain time to be mentioned in such presentment cause to be repaired such parts of the said road, as shall be described in the said presentment; and that in case the judge of aliize shall seal the said presentment, that the said treasurer shall be bound to cause the said road to be repaired pursuant to the said pre-lentment.

XIII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the said chief commissioners and their successors shall not, nor shall any of them, be answerable or accountable for any money to be received by virtue of this act, or under the trulls hereby reposed in them, any otherwise than each person for such sum and sums of money as he shall actually receive; and that no one of them shall be answerable or accountable for the other or others of them, or for the acts, receipts, neglects, or defaults of the other or others of them, but each and every of them for his own acts, receipts, neglects,' or defaults relpe'ctively; neither shall they or any of them be anftverable or accountable for any misfortune, loss, or damage, which may happen in the execution of any of the aforesaid trulls or in relation thereto, unless the same shall happen by or through his or their own wilful defaults respectively; and also that they the said trustees and their successors, or any four of them, shall and may with and out of such monies, as shall come to their respective hands by virtue of the aforesaid trulls, deduct and retain, and reimburse himself and themselves respectively, all colls, charges, damages, and expences, which they, or either, or any of them,"shall or may suffer, sustain, expend, disburse, be at, or be put unto, in the execution of any of the aforesaid trulls.
